stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on modeling and texturing the central tower for Course 11, tentatively naming the level 'Oily Boily Bay'. A major focus was implementing and animating a new power/health meter with assets provided by Biobak. Kaze also showcased reworks of older levels, discussed his game design philosophies, and shared personal anecdotes with his wife, Zeina.

development_findings.summary: Course 11, a level resembling an oil rig, has been tentatively named 'Oily Boily Bay' after Kaze found the alliterative, goofy name appealing and fun to say.
development_findings.quote: Oily Boily Bay, you know what, I'm gonna just set that as a temporary name. I think it's a pretty stupid name, but I still kinda like it.

development_findings.summary: The camera controls have been significantly updated to address complaints of input lag. C-left/right now provide instant rotation, while the D-pad offers a slower, hold-to-rotate option.
development_findings.quote: We have C left and right to rotate the camera. We're back now. Holding to rotate is gone. But instead on the D-pad, you can hold to rotate slowly like this.

development_findings.summary: The breath meter was intentionally made shorter than in the original SM64 to prevent players from freely exploring underwater areas without using intended mechanics like riding a Koopa shell.
development_findings.quote: The reason I wanted it shorter than vanilla is because in this level you'd be able to just get everywhere. And I don't want that to happen.

development_findings.summary: The team is considering using a new microcode (from Sauraen) that can disable near clipping, which could resolve significant camera problems, particularly in levels with complex geometry.
development_findings.quote: I've also been told about a new microcode today that we might want to use. The microcode allows you to disable near clipping so that would solve some of our camera issues.

development_findings.summary: Following a suggestion, Kaze implemented smooth animations for the power meter, making it scale in upon appearing and refill gradually instead of instantly.
development_findings.quote: I can do that. Yeah, I see what you mean. I'll make that note. We'll do that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explained the technical implementation of the circular breath meter, which uses two textures: one for the visual ring and a second, a circular gradient, to control an alpha threshold that makes the meter appear to deplete.
Kaze intentionally uses simple, descriptive variable names like 'farawayness' instead of technical terms, prioritizing clarity and universal understanding over industry jargon.
development_findings.quote: I prefer far awayness. Parallax factor means you need to understand the concept of a parallax. Far awayness everyone knows what far awayness is.

development_findings.summary: Multiple early levels from the demo, including 'Deep Dives Through the Dorms' (Course 1) and 'Turtle Street' (Course 2), have been completely reworked with different layouts and improved performance.
Kaze rejected an idea to have the health meter 'flip like a coin' to become the breath meter, believing the animation would feel strange to the player.
development_findings.quote: I think that would feel very weird to see your health bar flip.

context_findings.summary: Kaze now has a full-time job as a programmer at a video game company, which significantly limits the time he can dedicate to ROM hacking and streaming.
context_findings.quote: I am also very busy with my actual real job that pays my bills now. I have one. ROM making is not that lucrative, so I had to get a job other than that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong philosophical belief that a foundational understanding of assembly language is essential for truly comprehending higher-level languages like C.
context_findings.quote: I think you should not learn C until you've learned assembly. Learning C before you've learned assembly is like explaining color to a blind person.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to creating a high-quality, lasting game experience, actively rejecting suggestions that would turn the project into a collection of memes.
context_findings.quote: You might say I'm stuck up for actually making sure that my game is not just a meme, but this is what I want in my life. I want a game that keeps me occupied for the long term.

context_findings.summary: In works of fiction, Kaze prioritizes world-building and setting over character development, finding them more engaging and relatable.
context_findings.quote: I derive my joy from like the world and the setting and stuff like that. So that's really what I'm looking out for.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has an intense work ethic, stating he doesn't mind working up to 70 hours a week between his job and personal projects.
context_findings.quote: I don't mind working 70-hour weeks. I'm kind of just a little different.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a deep-seated personal disappointment with Super Mario Sunshine, citing its design issues as particularly painful to him.
context_findings.quote: It's maybe it's not the worst game. But it's the game that hurt me the most.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, rescued a baby bird they found in their parking lot, nursing it back to health in a box before it flew away the next day.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed the new power meter/health meter UI sprites, collaborating with Kaze through multiple iterations to perfect the color gradient and ensure consistent brightness.
biobak.quote: Me and Biobak, we went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right. Because I didn't want the brightness to increase from blue to green.

biobak.summary: Biobak created a custom Bowser logo for the tower in 'Oily Boily Bay' during the stream, providing the asset for Kaze to implement immediately.
Biobak provided real-time feedback and suggestions in chat, contributing to the evolving design of the level and UI elements.

zeina.summary: Zeina humorously discusses Kaze's intense work habits, particularly his idea of streaming for eight hours a day during his vacation, and plans her life around his demanding schedule.
zeina.quote: I'll just go visit my parents if you're gonna do the eight-hour stream. He's just gonna go there be like, yeah, my husband's kind of just fucking insane right now. I have to get out.

zeina.summary: Zeina engages in playful banter with Kaze about their personal life, including their cooking abilities and family dynamics, providing insight into their relationship.
zeina.quote: Wait, are you saying I can't cook? I've been saying you can't cook since I married you.

zeina.summary: Zeina participated in the rescue of a baby bird with Kaze, recounting the story on stream.

key_stories.title: Power Meter Redesign and Animation
key_stories.summary: The team collaborated to redesign the power meter. Biobak created the visual assets with iterative feedback from Kaze, who then implemented them and added dynamic animations for a more polished feel.
key_stories.challenge: The existing power/health meter UI felt dated. The team needed a cleaner, more modern design that fit the game's aesthetic.
key_stories.process: Biobak created new sprites for the meter. Kaze provided specific feedback on the color gradient to ensure visual consistency. After implementing the static assets, Kaze took a community suggestion and coded new animations for the meter appearing and refilling, resolving technical hurdles with matrix transformations to prevent it from breaking the pause menu.
key_stories.outcome: A new, cleaner power meter was successfully implemented. Kaze also added smooth scaling and refilling animations, resulting in a polished UI element that the team is very happy with.
key_stories.key_quote: Me and Biobak, we went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right. Because I didn't want the brightness to increase from blue to green.

key_stories.title: Designing Bowser's Tower Logo
key_stories.summary: To give the plain tower in Course 11 more personality, Kaze and Biobak collaborated in real-time. After rejecting several concepts, they decided on a corporate-style logo, which Biobak designed and Kaze implemented during the stream.
key_stories.challenge: The central tower in the oil rig level (Course 11) looked plain and lacked a distinct 'Bowser' feel.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas, rejecting a 'Bowser mouth' entrance as clich√©. He considered a neon-lit Yakuza style but felt it clashed with the level's aesthetic. He decided a large logo was the best solution. Biobak designed and sent a logo during the stream, which Kaze immediately implemented and began refining the UV mapping for.
key_stories.outcome: The tower now features a large, custom Bowser logo designed by Biobak. This gives the structure a clear identity as a corporate Bowser building and serves as a central visual anchor.
key_stories.key_quote: I feel like something's missing though... I don't want to put a Bowser face on there but you know something like that.

key_stories.title: The Dream Toads Collectible
key_stories.summary: Inspired by a dream, Kaze is implementing a new collectible system. Players will be able to find three hidden Toads who, when all found, will play a special song in the overworld.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to add a fun, optional collectible to the game that wasn't tied to core progression.
key_stories.process: Kaze had a vivid dream about Toads playing instruments poorly at the final boss. He found the idea amusing and decided to adapt a version of it for the game. He refined the concept from four poorly-playing Toads to three Toads who will perform a proper song as a reward.
key_stories.outcome: The game will now feature three hidden Toads across the overworlds. Finding all of them will unlock a special musical performance in the overworld, serving as a quirky Easter egg for players.
key_stories.key_quote: In my dream I had put four totes over my game and they won't all play an instrument very poorly... And you know what? I'm kinda doing this.
